Liquid: First Steps

Note: Before you begin working with Liquid you have to make sure that the plug-in is loaded correctly, please see the installation instructions.

When Maya starts and Liquid is loaded there should be a new option on the main menu called Liquid - this is Liquid's main menu and where you will most likely access most of it's features. Select the menu and familiarize yourself with the options.

We'll go through rendering a simple scene first. Create a nurbs sphere and make sure it's centered on the view, now create a directional light and check to make sure the sphere is catching some of the light. Choose preview under the liquid menu and wait for it to render. You should see the ball lit as you would expect when the render is complete.

To add a better looking surface or shader to your sphere you'll have to use Fluid. Under the Liquid menu choose Fluid and a new window will pop up. Fluid is Liquid's shader tool, used for assigning and editing a shaders parameters in the scene. On the left side of the window is a list of all the current shaders in the scene, on the right a file browser. Use the browser to find the shader that you want to load and either right click on the file and choose load or double click on it. An instance of the shader should now appear on the left side of the Fluid window. Right click on the instances name and a menu will appear, these are the various operations you can perform on the shaders. Select the sphere and choose assign from the menu. Preview the scene again to see the changes, the sphere should have your shader attached.
